name: Maristan
theoryOfChange: Reviving the Islamic legacy of Maristans by integrating Islamic principles (Ilm al-Nafs) with evidence-based mental health practices to provide culturally congruent care and education.

evaluationSources: Stanford Muslim Mental Health & Islamic Psychology Lab (Research Partner)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Limited match due to weaker results and/or higher uncertainty; review methodology details before deciding.

components.evidence: Accepts zakat (+2); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Asnaf: masakin (+5); Humanitarian service (+2)
components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.
components.name: Underserved Space

alignment.rationale: Alignment 31/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, global health cause area

components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: If reserves are above policy target, document why and publish triggers for planned deployment.

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with an explicit causal pathway.

components.evidence: Board governance: baseline (1 members, emerging org)

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 1 members

score_details.score_summary: Maristan shows good alignment and moderate impact, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

all_citations.claim: Maristan is a community mental health organization with 13.3 months of working capital.
The organization reported total revenue of $618,632 and a fundraising efficiency of $0.11 per $1 raised.
Maristan's programs include the Maristan Clinic, education, and training.
The organization provides donation options and is identified as Zakat-eligible.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: Maristan earns a moderate score of 49/100, reflecting a balance between efficient fundraising and healthy working capital against a lack of comprehensive impact data and external transparency ratings.
areas_for_improvement: Low data confidence due to limited third-party verification
Need for more robust public impact reporting and outcome metrics

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 31/50, Maristan addresses the urgent global health need for mental health services [1]. The organization is Zakat-eligible, providing a medium fit for Muslim donors seeking to support community-based clinical care [4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization focuses on capacity building through the Maristan Clinic and specialized education programs [3]. While it maintains a healthy 13.3 months of working capital, the overall impact score of 23/50 is limited by a lack of specific cost-per-beneficiary data and low data confidence [1][2].

baseline_narrative.headline: Maristan is a community mental health organization dedicated to providing culturally sensitive clinical care and education.
strengths: Strong liquidity with 13.3 months of working capital available
High fundraising efficiency with costs of only $0.11 per $1 raised
Designated as a Zakat-eligible organization for donors
baseline_narrative.summary: Maristan operates as a non-profit focused on community mental health through its clinical services and training programs [1][3]. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported a total revenue of $618,632 to support its mission [2].

all_citations.claim: Maristan Clinic, research, and suicide response certification training
all_citations.quote: Maristan Clinic, Education and Training, Research, Healing Circles, Suicide Response Certification Training

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization currently has a <cite id="2">board size of 1 member</cite>, which limits independent oversight for an emerging non-profit.
There is <cite id="1">insufficient data for cost-per-beneficiary calculation</cite>, making it difficult for donors to assess quantitative impact.

bbb_assessment.summary: This organization has not yet been reviewed by the BBB Wise Giving Alliance.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization is in a rapid growth phase and is developing its theory of change and reporting structures.
risk_factors: <cite id="1">Program expense ratio data is currently incomplete</cite>
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="2">limited governance oversight</cite> and a lack of granular expense data.

confidence.notes: Limited transparency data available for this emerging organization.

alignment.explanation: The organization shows medium alignment for Muslim donors by <cite id="4">accepting zakat</cite> and serving the 'masakin' (needy) through <cite id="3">culturally sensitive mental health care</cite>.
alignment.improvement: Alignment could be improved by <cite id="4">clarifying the specific zakat allocation policy</cite> and eligible use categories for donors.

credibility.explanation: Credibility is currently grounded in <cite id="2">official Form 990 filings</cite> and a documented mission, though data confidence is low due to <cite id="1">limited third-party verification</cite> and a small board.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization should expand its board and <cite id="1">publish audited financial statements</cite> to increase transparency.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="3">capacity-building model</cite> that includes clinician training and research, supported by <cite id="1">high working capital</cite>.
impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="1">consistently publishing beneficiary counts</cite> to allow for cost-effectiveness analysis.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Documented Theory of Change with qualitative outcomes

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct service delivery and capacity building

rich_narrative.headline: Maristan is a community mental health organization dedicated to providing culturally sensitive clinical care and education.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support the professionalization of Muslim mental health services and value culturally-congruent clinical care.
donor_motivations: Want to address the mental health crisis within the Muslim community
Value the integration of faith and science in healthcare
giving_considerations: The organization is still maturing its governance and transparency reporting
Gifts support both direct clinical care and long-term research/training
Rapid growth suggests a high need for flexible funding
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors who require long-standing institutional history or those who prioritize organizations with large, independent boards of directors.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects a verified theory of change and qualitative outcome tracking, but lacks rigorous independent evaluations or RCTs.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: Maristan creates impact by training clinicians in culturally sensitive practices and providing direct care, leading to <cite id="3">improved psychological flexibility</cite>.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that spiritual and clinical interventions effectively reduce self-harm and improve community well-being.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: As a rapidly growing organization in a high-demand field, Maristan can absorb significant capital to expand its clinic and training reach.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its <cite id="3">integration of Islamic tradition</cite> with clinical psychology, a niche underserved by mainstream providers.

strengths.detail: The organization maintains <cite id="1">13.3 months of working capital</cite>, providing a strong safety net for sustained operations.
Maristan operates with high efficiency, spending only <cite id="1">$0.11 to raise every $1</cite> in contributions.
Beyond clinical care, they offer unique <cite id="3">Suicide Response Certification Training</cite> tailored for community leaders.

strengths_deep_dive: Maristan's financial health is characterized by robust liquidity and efficient resource mobilization. With <cite id="1">13.3 months of working capital</cite> available, the organization is well-positioned to weather economic fluctuations while expanding its <cite id="3">Education and Training programs</cite>. Their revenue model is diversifying, with <cite id="2">$147,687 generated from program service revenue</cite> alongside traditional contributions. This fiscal stability supports a wide array of initiatives, from <cite id="3">clinical services to research</cite> aimed at improving psychological flexibility and mental health outcomes within the Muslim American population.
rich_narrative.summary: Maristan is a community mental health organization that bridges the gap between Islamic tradition and modern psychology to provide <cite id="1">culturally sensitive clinical care and education</cite>. Operating primarily in the United States, the organization addresses critical gaps in mental health services for Muslim communities through a multi-faceted approach including the <cite id="3">Maristan Clinic, research, and suicide response certification training</cite>. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization demonstrated significant growth, reporting <cite id="2">total revenue of $618,632</cite>, a substantial increase from the previous year. This growth is reflected in a <cite id="2">3-year revenue CAGR of 376.0%</cite>, indicating a rapidly scaling institution. While the organization is in an early maturity stage, it has already established a <cite id="3">documented theory of change</cite> and provides specialized services such as <cite id="3">Healing Circles and clinician training</cite> to ensure that mental health support is both spiritually congruent and clinically rigorous.
